summary: Paul Merson resumed his criticism of Andros Townsend, particularly after Townsend was brought on late in Tottenham's draw with Burnley. Merson had previously doubted Townsend's suitability for the England team, but Townsend scored a notable equalizer against Italy, prompting Merson to admit his mistake. Townsend responded to Merson's criticism via Twitter, and although their tension appeared to ease, Merson made another sarcastic comment after Tottenham's recent match.

Chelsea has made a formal offer to acquire FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, who would join Vitesse Arnhem on loan if the transfer completes. FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane stated that the interest is unrelated to Chelsea's sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who graduated from Keio University recently, has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo, earned 11 caps for Japan, and was named in the J-League's best XI. Although pleased with Chelsea's offer, Muto has not decided whether to join the club. The proposed transfer deal is around £4 million.

A large-scale study has found that babies given antibiotics within their first six months are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers, particularly boys. The researchers suggest antibiotics may contribute to the childhood obesity epidemic by disrupting gut bacteria, which can affect food digestion and appetite. While the study doesn't prove causation, it highlights the importance of cautious antibiotic use in infancy, given their potential impact on weight and health. The findings add to concerns about over-prescription of antibiotics and its broader health consequences, including increasing antibiotic resistance and related risks.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, an incident caught on camera by a tourist. The guard lost his footing, knocked over his bearskin and rifle, and quickly got back up as colleagues continued marching. The event, witnessed by many tourists, was prompted by the metal protectors on the soles of his boots causing the slip. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment, and the guard appeared embarrassed by the incident.

A&E Networks, along with Lifetime and History, are remaking the famous 1977 miniseries "Roots" to air in 2016, focusing on the story of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery in America. The new version will be more "original" and "contemporary," drawing from Alex Haley's novel, and will include input from scholars to enhance authenticity. LeVar Burton, who starred as Kinte in the original, will serve as co-executive producer. The remake aims to introduce the powerful story to a new generation amid current themes of racial unrest and historical milestones like Barack Obama's presidency.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, has accused Clarence House aides of attempting to force him into an orgy in January 1978, during his first shift at the Queen Mother’s London residence. Lawler, who was 27 at the time, claimed he was assaulted after entering a bedroom, where he was offered a drink and approached by staff members. He rebuffed their advances, managed to escape, and reported the incident immediately, but his complaint was initially ignored. He later contacted palace officials again last year amid investigations into historical child abuse allegations, but his claims were initially dismissed before being referred to Scotland Yard. Police are now investigating these claims, and the Royal Household has pledged full cooperation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy through a rap parody video set to the theme song of 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air,' which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube. The video features them rapping in a car about their journey to parenthood, culminating in sharing a sonogram of their unborn child. The couple, who live in Happy Valley, Oregon, explained the background and motivations for the video, expressing surprise at its popularity. Jesse is a descendant of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek. Additionally, Melissa previously made a video capturing Jesse’s reaction to learning about the pregnancy through a message on their dog.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind* sold for $137,000 at auction. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble was used in key scenes and has faded from its original slate blue-gray color. The dress was part of a collection amassed by James Tumblin, who bought it in the 1960s for $20. The auction included over 150 items from the film, with other notable sales including Leigh's straw hat for $52,500, Gable's costume pieces for $55,000, and a bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia DeHavilland for $30,000. *Gone With the Wind* celebrated its 75th anniversary and featured notable cast members, including Hattie McDaniel, the first African-American to win an Oscar.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. He was rescued by his parents before assistance arrived and suffered minor injuries, including an injured leg, but was in stable condition at the hospital. The zoo reported eyewitness accounts indicating the child was likely dangled over the railing, and plans to press child endangerment charges against the child's family. The exhibit was subsequently closed, and the cheetahs did not attack the boy, possibly due to their fear or curiosity.

A speed camera in Birmingham, which had not been operational for over two years since fixed devices were decommissioned in 2013, has been turned to face a house. The camera is part of region-wide removal of outdated technology, replaced by mobile units and patrols. Birmingham City Council is aware of the re-pointed camera; an engineer will assess it, but it is not included in upcoming digital pilot programs. The house owners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. He is fit and eager to run, aiming to contribute to Jamaica's tradition of relay success. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed pleasure that Bolt would be participating, promising an exciting event. The full team will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves supported Barcelona’s basketball team during an El Clasico match, which Barcelona narrowly won 85-80 over Real Madrid in the Euro League; Neymar also helped Brazil beat Chile 1-0 at the Emirates Stadium and led Brazil to victory in a lively contest. Prior to the international break, Barcelona, with Neymar, was four points ahead in La Liga, and they are preparing to face Celta Vigo as they pursue multiple trophies. Neymar's sister Rafaella attended the basketball game, and Neymar was involved in a match where Gary Medel was seen walking off after apparently stamping on Neymar.

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrant crossings from Africa and the Middle East into Europe, with over 8,400 rescued between Friday and Monday. There are fears that around 400 migrants may be missing after a ship carrying 550 people reportedly capsized off Libya, but Italian authorities have not confirmed this incident. Since the start of 2015, more than 10,000 migrants have arrived in Italy, mainly from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, often using Libya as a transit country. The International Organization for Migration reports at least 480 migrant deaths this year due to bad weather, overcrowded vessels, and abandonment by smugglers. Last week saw nearly 1,000 migrants rescued in a single day.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool, though he does not know Sanchez’s exact reasons. Sanchez, who had multiple club offers after leaving Barcelona, decided to sign with Arsenal following the World Cup and has since made an immediate impact by scoring 19 goals in the season. Wenger suggests that Liverpool’s interest may have influenced negotiations related to Luis Suarez's transfer to Barcelona. He praises Sanchez’s quick adaptation and attributes his effective performance to his qualities, work rate, and fighting spirit. Wenger also downplays rumors of a potential transfer of Liverpool’s Raheem Sterling to Arsenal, despite Sterling’s rejection of a new contract and Liverpool’s recent challenges.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome, aiming to set a distance that could remain a long-standing mark. Wiggins, a four-time Olympic gold medallist and former Tour de France winner, is motivated by the event's historic significance and personal challenge. The current record is 52.491 km, set by Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins plans to race in front of a crowd of around 6,000, with tickets on sale from April 19 and the event broadcast live on Sky Sports. He will prepare for this attempt following his recent Paris-Roubaix race and upcoming participation in the Tour de Yorkshire. The event seeks to inspire recreational cyclists and is part of Wiggins’ broader Olympic ambitions, targeting his eighth Olympic medal at Rio 2016.

Serena Williams, a twice French Open champion, struggled during her Fed Cup match against Sara Errani, ultimately winning in three sets but acknowledging her unpreparedness for the claycourt season. The US team lost the tie 3-2 after doubles defeat and was relegated to World Group II. Williams, who has won 19 singles Grand Slams, recognized the need to adjust her play for clay and emphasized the importance of better preparation to regain top status in future competitions.

River Plate is interested in signing Radamel Falcao, who previously played for the club before transferring to Porto in 2009. The club's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed a desire for Falcao to return, stating that "the doors are open." Falcao, who is currently on loan at Manchester United and has scored four Premier League goals this season, has struggled at United but has recently scored three goals in two matches for Colombia, reaching 24 international goals. Falcao previously played for River Plate at age 15, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances during his four seasons with the Argentine club.

Ella Henderson, a finalist from The X Factor in 2012, has become the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' dry shampoo campaign. This is her first brand collaboration, featuring images of her with various hairstyles against a city background. Henderson, who uses the product regularly, is excited about the partnership. The campaign, launched with a TV advertisement featuring her single "Mirror Man," was organized by the MILES agency, and her management highlights this as her inaugural endorsement.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, who was shot and killed by officer Pablo Torres in Kenosha, Wisconsin, last month, are upset over a billboard honoring Torres that was erected by the Kenosha Police Association. The billboard features Torres and his dog with a message thanking the community for support, which Siler’s family and friends find disrespectful. They feel it implies gratitude for Siler’s death, especially since Siler was shot after he armed himself with a weapon following a confrontation with Torres. Torres is currently on leave pending an investigation into the shooting, which is still ongoing. Siler’s shooting occurred after a vehicle and foot pursuit, and it followed a previous incident where Torres shot a man armed with knives. The police association states the billboard was meant to thank the community and not to offend.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Iran-Pakistan border, with three militants also killed. The militants, identified as Jaish al Adal, crossed from Pakistan into Iran and have previously targeted Iranian territory and security forces. Iran has called on Pakistan to arrest the surviving militants, while Pakistan condemned the attack and is investigating. Jaish al Adal is an anti-Iranian Sunni group active in Balochistan, aiming to oppose Iranian influence.

The passage discusses Japan's recent political discussion regarding UFOs, with Defense Minister Gen Nakatani confirming that Japan's Air Self Defense Force has never encountered extraterrestrial UFOs. Inoki, a former wrestler and politician, inquired about UFO sightings and research, and claimed he has seen a UFO himself but is unsure about alien existence. The article also notes that Japanese politicians have previously debated the legal considerations of defending against potential space threats.

Passenger Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalised with deep cuts after breaking a poorly built toilet at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport. He was standing on the toilet rim to avoid contact with the seat when it collapsed and shattered, causing injuries that required stitches. Jin Pai initially claimed he was sitting when the incident occurred but later told police he was squatting, possibly to avoid compensation. Authorities considered the event an accident and reminded visitors to sit on toilets rather than stand on them.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom, which he used to record her and others over four years. The investigation revealed that Rebbie had been watching her undress and sleep, molesting her from ages nine to 13. Authorities found 41 videos from the camera, some showing victims showering, which Rebbie uploaded to his computer. He admitted to filming multiple victims, including other juveniles. Rebbie faces charges such as aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy, and is held on $500,000 bail pending a preliminary hearing on May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's series captures fathers in sharp suits leaping into the air next to their daughters, who pose with neutral expressions. The images, part of his book "Daughter and Salary Man," aim to show fathers expressing their fun side through energetic jumps, despite age-related challenges. The photos often feature families in front of Japanese landmarks and have garnered online interest for their curious approach.

The passage discusses Kevin Pietersen's involvement with Surrey ahead of the County Championship season, following the sacking of England's managing director Paul Downton. Pietersen, who last played for England during the 2014 Ashes series, appears to be contemplating a potential return to the England team, especially as England aims to regain the Ashes on home soil. During a team photo at the KIA Oval, Pietersen was in a jovial mood, joking with teammates and photographers, and taking pictures himself. His return to Surrey is seen as a step toward re-entering the international cricket set-up amid ongoing speculation about his role in England's future matches.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, threatened with relegation, dismissed and then reinstated Brazilian coach Ze Maria within a week due to poor performance and an angry owner. After a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani left the team 16th in the standings, Ze Maria was sacked and replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Nabil Dirar believes Radamel Falcao regrets his failed loan move to Manchester United, as he was unhappy in France and not performing well due to a serious knee injury. Falcao, who struggled during his season-long loan at United, scored only four goals, and United is unlikely to make his transfer permanent for £46 million. Dirar suggests Falcao would have fared better staying at Monaco, where he would have played in the Champions League and felt more comfortable.

New Zealand police are seeking help to identify a tall man wearing a cartoon mask who robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday. The suspect, dressed in a fluoro orange sweatshirt and oversized mask, demanded cash from the owner's daughter, threw the cash register, and escaped with the till containing approximately $1,500. No weapons were used, and the robber remains at large. Police have released security footage and are asking the public to contact Crimestoppers or police with any information.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was first arrested in March for having an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, admitting to kissing him and allowing him to touch her breasts. She was suspended and placed on administrative leave. Subsequently, she was re-arrested after another 15-year-old pupil accused her of having sex with him on consecutive nights in January in her car. The second incident was uncovered following information from within the school. Granado was released on bail both times and her current legal status regarding the second charges is unclear. The school district stated that they took immediate action, including placing her on leave.

A video showing a large crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has been viewed over 500,000 times. The attack was witnessed by New Zealander Tim Weston, who noted the crocodile held the dog for hours. The area is known for crocodiles, which are common in local mangroves and the nearby sanctuary. Reactions on social media included horror and dislike for crocodiles.

Steve Bruce believes he can keep Hull City in the Premier League despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton, leaving them just two points above the relegation zone with six games remaining. The team has underperformed, with only six wins this season, despite a strong start, and recent setbacks are attributed to injuries to key players. Hull face tough fixtures against top teams, but Bruce remains confident that positive results can secure their safety. Southampton moved to fifth in the table after the win, while discussions arose at Southampton regarding a failed penalty attempt by Sadio Mane, which manager Ronald Koeman plans to address.

A teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Ian Guffick, was banned from the classroom after allowing pupils to alter their SATs answers, leading to the annulment of the school's results. Guffick also changed some answers himself after the exam session ended. An investigation found that some students changed answers outside exam conditions, prompting the Department for Education to nullify all of the school's SATs results for that year. Guffick admitted the allegations and accepted that his conduct was unacceptable, though he claimed he only asked students to make their answers more legible. A disciplinary panel concluded that no changes should be made outside test conditions and banned Guffick from teaching for at least two years, citing his deliberate actions and the serious impact on the school. He has 28 days to appeal the decision.

Anders Lindegaard, a goalkeeper at Manchester United who has made limited appearances and is now third-choice, is happily married to Swedish model Misse Beqiri. The couple, who have a son and have been together since 2012, married in a beach wedding in Mauritius last year. Off the pitch, Lindegaard enjoys spending time with Beqiri, sharing moments on Instagram. Despite his limited playing time and potential transfer from United, Lindegaard is reportedly doing well in his personal life.

Thirteen glowing blue letters from Yankee Stadium, owned by Reggie Jackson, failed to sell at Sotheby's auction, despite estimates of $300,000 to $600,000; the only bid was $260,000 from a Sotheby's employee. Jackson, who bought the signs after the stadium's 2008 final game, wanted a new generation to enjoy this iconic Yankees symbol. The auction also featured a Mets bullpen car, which sold for $112,500, surpassing its estimated value.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their responsibilities following a week where Sterling was caught inhaling nitrous oxide and both players were seen with shisha pipes. Neither player will face discipline, as Rodgers has chosen to move past the incidents. He emphasized the importance of professionalism and responsibility for young athletes. Rodgers also discussed the upcoming FA Cup semi-final, expressing his focus on progressing in the competition and highlighting the importance of learning from near misses in sports. Steven Gerrard is available after suspension for the match, but Rodgers has not confirmed if he will be recalled.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, returned to London after the international break, relaxing at home with his dog and preparing for an upcoming match against Liverpool. He performed well internationally, helping Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in Euro 2016 qualifying. Since returning from injury in January, Ozil has scored three goals and provided four assists, expressing that he is now adjusting well to English football's demanding schedule. Although he was briefly linked to nightclub visits during an illness absence, Arsenal's manager denied this. Ozil's playing style suits the frequent matches characteristic of English football, and he is in good form ahead of the upcoming Premier League game.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu stated that the club has no plans to replace manager Luis Enrique, expressing satisfaction with his performance. Enrique, who took charge last summer on a two-year deal, is close to winning the La Liga title and is focusing on upcoming matches. Despite speculation about his future, Bartomeu emphasized the club's happiness with him and highlighted his dedication, noting his contract runs until 2016.

Jordan Henderson has signed a new long-term contract with Liverpool, running until 2020 and worth approximately £100,000 a week. The deal follows negotiations that began at the start of the season and makes him the third key player, after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho, to extend his contract. Henderson, 24, has been a significant improvement under Brendan Rodgers, contributing 13 assists and seven goals this season. He is also a potential captain candidate after Steven Gerrard's departure. While talks with Raheem Sterling are postponed until after the season, Liverpool's chief executive expects Sterling to stay long-term.

Filipe Luis remains committed to staying at Chelsea until his contract ends, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. Signed last July on a three-year contract, he has struggled for a regular starting position. Luis expressed his happiness at Chelsea and his desire to stay. He recently played in Brazil’s wins against France and Chile and is now focused on the Premier League title run-in. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho emphasizes the importance of focus and winning every game, with nine challenging matches ahead.

Nathan Hughes’s three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North was overturned on appeal, as the panel ruled there was no foul play and the incident was accidental. Originally suspended for reckless conduct, the ban was rescinded amid criticism from players and club officials. The incident involved Hughes’s knee colliding with North’s head while scoring, leaving North unconscious and requiring a month off for concussion recovery. The appeal panel found no foul play after reviewing new evidence, allowing Hughes to return to play immediately.

A fiery red sunset in Washington was caused by smoke from raging Siberian wildfires, which started due to farmers' grass burning that became uncontrolled. Winds spread the smoke across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, creating intense red and orange hues in sunsets by filtering out shorter wavelengths of light. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve, and the sunsets will lose their reddish appearance.

Becky Schoenig's 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her driveway in Missouri. It was later found with minor modifications, such as red rims and detailing, after a tip from Mick Sexton. Schoenig humorously thanked the thieves for "pimping out" her car on Facebook. She is now getting the car cleaned due to odors and is creating a smoothie named after Sexton to honor him.

Manchester City players face losing around £500,000 in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League, as their incentivized contracts depend on reaching Europe's top competition. The team is currently in fourth place, with their European qualification contingent on finishing in the top four of the Premier League. City has dropped in form after an initial strong start in 2015, with recent losses and early exits in cup competitions. The club has approximately £12 million riding on their ability to secure European qualification. The manager has acknowledged poor performance and needs to improve to maintain their European ambitions and attract top players.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated City 1-0 in a match showcasing local talent and skilled play, with Callum Gribbin scoring the winning free-kick. The game, held at Moss Lane with free entry and a large crowd, reflected a match-like experience for United's youth players, who lined up with a formation similar to the first team. Despite missed opportunities by Marcus Rashford for United and City creating several chances, United secured their victory, moving closer to the league leaders. The match highlighted promising talents from both sides, raising hopes for potential first-team opportunities amidst ongoing development debates.

Joe Hart praised Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" after Buffon earned his 147th cap, calling him an inspiration. Hart, who reached his 50th cap for England, expressed admiration for Buffon's longevity and professionalism. The 37-year-old Buffon’s caps total is significantly higher, and Hart hopes to continue increasing his own international appearances by performing well for his club and country.

Chipotle is partnering with Postmates to offer delivery of online and mobile orders in 67 cities, tapping into the $70 billion food delivery market. Customers will face a 9% service charge and delivery fees starting at $5, varying by distance and demand. The app employs independent contractors with personal vehicles. Chipotle had previously declined third-party delivery offers but has now adopted this model. The move aligns with a trend of major brands like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King exploring or expanding delivery services. Notably, both presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton were recently spotted visiting Chipotle, highlighting its popularity among public figures.

The parents of the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, Martin Richard, have made an emotional plea opposing the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted on all charges related to the 2013 attack. They describe the severe suffering they endured, including the loss of their son and injuries to their daughter. Despite acknowledging the heinousness of the crimes, they support sentencing Tsarnaev to life in prison without parole instead of the death penalty, hoping it would prevent prolonged legal appeals and help their family and the community move forward.

The passage describes a custom-built Boeing 747 converted into a luxury home for an anonymous billionaire, costing around £400 million. Designed for a single owner with space for dozens of guests, it features bedrooms, lounges, a dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a 'state room,' and an 'aeroloft' with eight beds. The interior resembles a luxury hotel with plush decor, a conference room, an office/guest room with porthole windows, and a main suite with high-end furnishings. Parts of the plane are designated for relaxation and entertainment, including a television area, emphasizing its ultra-luxurious, exclusive nature, far surpassing typical commercial first-class amenities.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying the uncrewed Dragon spacecraft to the International Space Station from Cape Canaveral. The rocket's first stage attempted to land on a drone ship but tipped over and was unsuccessful; this was part of Musk's goal to reuse rockets to reduce costs. The Dragon delivered over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the station, including an espresso maker, and will be repaired for about five weeks before returning with science experiments and waste. This was SpaceX's sixth mission to the ISS, and the second attempt after a weather delay.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the inaugural wedding at the new Elvis Presley-themed chapel in Las Vegas's Westgate Hotel, where Elvis performed numerous shows. The event is part of a contest launched by NBC's Today show, offering an Elvis-obsessed couple a chance to win a free wedding, reception, hotel stay, airfare, and concert tickets. The winning couple, announced next Monday, will marry on April 23 at the chapel, which is linked to the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis. Priscilla emphasized that the event will be of high quality and that no impersonators will be involved. Couples interested must submit a video or photos explaining why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes the team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League and is optimistic about their chances after recent good form. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both played their 47th game of the season, equaling a record in top European leagues. Liverpool's recent 2-0 victory over Newcastle United, which included key goals from Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen, helped them close the points gap to City, who have been struggling. Henderson emphasized the importance of maintaining winning performances, expressing hope that the team’s efforts could lead to overtaking City by the season's end.

Roma ended a four-month home winless streak by defeating Napoli in Serie A, with Miralem Pjanic scoring in the 25th minute and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis making key saves in the second half. The victory moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of Lazio and ended Napoli's five-match winless run. The match was security-tight due to previous fan violence, and Roma was without injured captains Totti and Gervinho. De Sanctis played a crucial role in securing the win, especially with multiple saves late in the game.

Doncaster Rovers had a disappointing season in League One, currently in mid-table. Their recent match against Fleetwood Town ended in a 0-0 draw, offering little excitement. Due to the lack of goals, the club's media team created a brief 27-second highlight video, mainly showing the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle, making it a concise summary of the match.

A man named Roland Giroux interacts closely with his blood parrot cichlid by gently massaging and stroking it inside its tank. The fish, which was previously bullied by other tank mates, becomes more sociable and enjoys these daily 15-minute interactions, often swimming around Giroux's fingers and following his hand. Giroux notes that the fish relaxes and shows frustration if not played with regularly. The blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid first bred in Taiwan in 1986, benefits from this social interaction, which Giroux documents on his YouTube channel.

Ben Stokes is a fiery and passionate cricketer who has faced ups and downs over the past year. He returned to the England team with a strong character, demonstrating aggression and enthusiasm, but his behavior requires careful management to channel his energy productively. Stokes has a history of intense moments, such as breaking his wrist after an incident in the dressing room and clashing with players on the field. England coaches, including Peter Moores, have provided guidance to help him control his aggression while maintaining his natural exuberance. The team values his presence and potential, encouraging him to express his fiery nature but within controlled limits, aiming to maximize his contributions with runs and wickets. The team also considers options like playing two spinners, with hopes for both Stokes and other players like Adil Rashid to develop further into key international contributors.

The passage discusses Wales' crucial Euro 2016 qualifying match against Belgium at the Cardiff City Stadium on June 12, which has sold out for 33,000 tickets. Both teams are tied on 11 points in Group B, with Belgium leading on goal difference. Wales, after a 3-0 victory over Israel, is optimistic about qualifying for the tournament in France. Due to high demand, general admission tickets for the match are sold out. Although there was speculation about playing at the larger Millennium Stadium, UEFA rules prevented venue changes within 120 days, so the match will be held at Cardiff City Stadium, which Wales prefers.

England coach John Peacock has named his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where England is the defending champion. The team, which qualified with a perfect record, is placed in Group D with Holland, Italy, and Ireland; they will open against Italy on May 7. The squad includes players from several Premier League clubs, such as Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi (first call-up), Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold (recall), and others. England's other matches are against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht midfielder Evangelos Patoulidis, a highly regarded youth talent also linked to Arsenal and Barcelona. The teenager previously rejected a move to Barcelona's La Masia to focus on studies. City has discussed compensation with Anderlecht, with coach Manuel Pellegrini aiming to develop the young player for the future.

A 33-year-old transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found strangled and beaten in a flat in Fulham, London, at the end of March and was pronounced dead at the scene. She had been working as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death and bailed for further questioning. Police are appealing for anyone who had contact with her shortly before her death and are investigating her professional background and social media activity.

Dawn, a woman who had seven miscarriages and planned to purchase a gravestone for her lost baby Daniel James, discovered that £207, intended for the stone, was stolen. She suspected her housemate Jamie and confronted him, leading to a lie detector test on The Jeremy Kyle Show, which revealed Jamie had stolen the money. Jamie also sent Dawn a Facebook message confessing to the theft and blaming his girlfriend Carol. Distressed by the betrayal and the loss of funds meant for her baby's grave, Dawn broke down in tears during the show and expressed her feelings of hurt and betrayal.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, mostly women and children, from captivity in northern Iraq, with Arab tribal leaders reportedly helping coordinate the release. The Yazidis, a Kurdish minority persecuted for centuries and targeted by ISIS, were previously subjected to slaughter, rape, and enslavement during ISIS's upheaval last summer. Most of the released individuals were received by the Peshmerga forces and taken to Irbil. The exact motivation for the release remains unclear.

Harry Kane, a Tottenham striker, has had an exceptional season, leading to his nominations for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. Celebrated for his on-pitch achievements, he is now also featured in an animated video by Copa90 that showcases his top goals and celebrations. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', highlights key moments like his goals against Newcastle, Chelsea, Arsenal, and England debut, and was released ahead of the awards ceremony where he competes against players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers remaining as Liverpool's manager despite recent seasons without trophies and potential failure to qualify for the Champions League. Carragher emphasized that a manager's future should not be judged on one game and highlighted ongoing efforts to improve the team. He noted Liverpool's current points deficit and poor performances, including an FA Cup semi-final exit, and stressed the importance of successful signings. Carragher, also a community award recipient for his work in Merseyside, expressed hope that Rodgers will continue to lead the team and shared his personal commitment to supporting underprivileged communities.

A four-year-old boy, James Hayward, had his plastic toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport during security checks, which included a pat-down, because the toy was deemed a security risk. His father criticized the security process as over-zealous and inconvenient, especially since the toy was harmless. After returning from their holiday in Lanzarote, the family bought James a new toy gun. The airport apologized and explained that regulations prohibit items resembling replica guns from passing through security, citing safety protocols set by the government.

A man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an online ad seeking a partner, outlining his preferences and qualities he offers. He described himself as athletic, tattooed, successful, and independent, and emphasized his interests in outdoors activities and cars. His ad detailed the qualities he desires in a woman, such as loving animals, being reliable, honest, fit, attractive, and skilled in household tasks and intimacy. He also mentioned offering benefits like free gym membership, a phone, and potential company car and accommodation. Rich expressed willingness to consider all reasonable offers and stated he is willing to spend generously on his partner, but his attempts to contact him have been unsuccessful.

Greg Dyke, FA chairman, seeks to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12 and adjust the criteria for 'home-grown' to have trained in England for three years before age 18. He faces opposition from the Premier League. Five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—support Dyke’s proposals, warning that blocking them risks England falling behind in international success. They highlight that only 36.8% of Premier League starters are eligible for England selection and emphasize the importance of providing opportunities for talented young players like Harry Kane, Ross Barkley, and Raheem Sterling. The managers acknowledge England's recent progress but argue that the shrinking pool of top English talent hampers national success.

Demelza Poldark has given birth to a baby girl, with her pregnancy progressing rapidly within the show's episodes. Fans note the implausibly quick timeline of her pregnancy, from being eight months along to childbirth occurring shortly after the announcement. The show also features Ross Poldark's love for Demelza and his feelings about their relationship, with fans expressing interest in his romantic prospects, though he appears committed to Demelza.

Nigel Pearson has urged Leicester to focus on their own performances and remain calm, despite being three points from safety after winning back-to-back matches. He emphasizes the importance of concentrating on their own run-in rather than worrying about relegation rivals or external factors, noting that other teams being involved in the relegation battle can be misleading. Pearson wants his players to stay focused to improve their chances of survival.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest mammal migration on record, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. Her journey exceeded previous records set by humpback whales. During her trip, she visited three major breeding areas, suggesting she is an eastern gray whale, which raises questions about the distinction between eastern and western gray whales, especially given the Western gray whale's critically low population of around 150.

Residents on Hokkaido Island's Shiretoko Peninsula experienced an unexpected appearance of land after 1,000ft of seabed was forced to the surface overnight, rising up to 50ft in some areas. The new landmass, measuring approximately 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide, resulted from a landslide caused by melting ice and snow, which displaced a section of land from underwater. The emergence was sudden, with no signs of tremors or sounds, and authorities do not expect further expansion. Marine life remains attached to the new land, and the event is distinct from earthquakes or the recent earthquake in Kathmandu.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors of leaving Paris Saint-Germain in the summer, expressing his happiness and love for the club, city, and teammates. Despite recent disagreements with manager Laurent Blanc over being dropped, van der Wiel intends to remain at PSG and plans to sign a new contract. His future may depend on team decisions, especially as PSG is linked with signing Barcelona's Dani Alves, which could potentially lead to van der Wiel's sale.

Carlos Tevez has expressed his desire to leave Juventus this summer to return to Boca Juniors, his former club in Argentina. Juventus, who have not yet officially released him and still see him as a key player, are reluctant to lose him but have acknowledged his wish to move. Tevez, 31, currently has a contract until 2016 and is close to completing a transfer to Boca Juniors, pending his termination of the Juventus contract. The player's international manager, Tata Martino, emphasized that Tevez's potential move wouldn't affect his Argentina national team future, and highlighted that both Juventus and Boca are strong clubs.

During Bayern Munich's 6-1 victory over Porto in the Champions League, manager Pep Guardiola tore a hole in his grey trousers, leaving his underwear visible. The match saw Bayern, who led 5-0 at half-time, overturn a two-goal deficit from the first leg to advance to the semi-finals, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and two from Robert Lewandowski. Guardiola joked about needing new trousers for future matches, and he also removed his blazer later in the game.

A multi-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale involved three cars and ten people, including four children. Three patients—two adults and one child—were airlifted to Brisbane's Princess Alexandra Hospital with injuries such as chest, shoulder, and arm pain. Six others, including an infant and young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor or assessment-only injuries. Emergency crews rescued one trapped individual using hydraulic tools. The highway was closed south of Fernvale, with diversions in place.

Mesut Ozil is excited for the upcoming Arsenal versus Chelsea match and has recently received a new Apple Watch, which he shared on Instagram, comparing it to Michael Knight's watch from Knight Rider. The watch, ranging from £299 to £13,500, was a gift from an Apple store visit. Ozil is expected to start in Sunday's match, which Arsenal trails Chelsea by 10 points with six games remaining. Additionally, Jack Wilshere has returned to fitness after five months out due to injury, and club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere's potential is contingent on his ability to stay fit, emphasizing his skills and future importance to the team.

Referee Mark Clattenburg has been appointed to officiate the Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City at Old Trafford. Despite having sent off three players this season—only two of whom were from United—he is chosen to referee the match. Clattenburg has occasionally faced controversy but is regarded as a leading Premier League referee. Manchester United, in strong form with five consecutive wins, aims to solidify their second-place position, while Manchester City, struggling since the start of the year, seeks to improve their standings. The match is significant, with the outcome potentially influencing final league positions.

Outspoken MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of viewing MP Billy Gordon as a "little black puppet on a string," implying they believed he would resign after being accused of domestic violence and withholding his criminal history. Katter, of Lebanese descent, expressed sympathy for Gordon and criticized the government’s assumptions. His comments sparked social media criticism over his use of racial terminology, which Katter defended as a personal reference to his background. He also compared Gordon's situation to federal independents who compromised their independence, asserting Gordon would not fall into that trap.

A 19-year-old from Illinois named Dayna Dobias, who has cerebral palsy, creates dance videos to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and judgment, she aims to change perceptions of people with disabilities by demonstrating that she can do things like walk, drive, and attend college. Dayna hopes her videos promote understanding and encourage people to see beyond disabilities, turning negativity into positivity. She also engages in motivational speaking at local schools to further her message.

Orlando City has shown interest in Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, aiming to leverage his popularity among their Latin-American fans, with inquiries made last week. Hernandez, who has recently struggled during a loan at Real Madrid, is also linked with eight European clubs including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan, with Manchester United willing to sell for around £8 million. Meanwhile, Manchester United has extended a revised contract offer to 19-year-old midfielder Andreas Pereira, who has other European clubs like PSG, Juventus, PSV, and Feyenoord interested if he doesn't accept United's terms.

A group of at least three people set fire to a white Dodge Charger at a South Los Angeles gas station early Saturday morning after an argument with the driver. The suspects attempted to carjack the driver, who fled after being confronted with a gun. They then poured gasoline on the car and ignited it while two passengers were inside. The passengers and driver were unharmed, but the car was completely destroyed. The incident is being investigated as arson by the Los Angeles County Fire Department, with surveillance video aiding the investigation, and the suspects remain at large.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, surrendered his license after admitting to accepting sex as payment and performing exorcisms on patients. He agreed not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years and must demonstrate that the circumstances leading to license revocation no longer exist before practicing again. Despite the misconduct, Manuel received positive patient satisfaction ratings. His practice was located at a residential address, and he also advised patients to stop taking prescribed medication.

The U.S. has lodged a diplomatic complaint with Russia after a Russian SU-27 intercepted a U.S. RC-135U over the Baltic Sea in an unsafe manner, with the incident occurring in international airspace north of Poland. The U.S. crew found the Russian pilot's actions aggressive and close-up, while Russia claimed the U.S. plane was heading toward the Russian border with its transponder off—an assertion the U.S. denies. The incident follows a previous dangerous encounter a year ago, highlighting frequent interceptions between U.S. and Russian aircraft in European and Arctic regions.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle, secured in a hard case and locked with chains and padlocks, was stolen overnight from his car parked at the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City, just days before President Obama visited Utah. The thief broke the rear passenger window, used a rope around the rifle case, and possibly used the momentum from another vehicle to forcefully remove the weapon, despite it being properly secured. Along with the rifle, the thief took the agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools. Police found broken window parts, skid marks, and rope nearby; the agent's bags were recovered at a nearby hotel, but the rifle remains missing. The hotel's lack of surveillance cameras and the presence of the theft just before the presidential visit have raised security concerns, with the rifle's serial number entered into national crime databases, but it is unclear if the theft was targeted.

Luigi Costa, aged 71, is accused of murdering his neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in 2012. A forensic psychiatrist testified that Costa was likely suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the attack, which affected his mental state and may have made him unaware of his actions. The court considered evidence such as fluctuating mood, a trail of faeces indicating confusion, and Costa's mental health history. The jury's verdict depends on whether Costa's mental instability at the time can be proven.

Everton's Ross Barkley took an unassigned penalty during a 1-0 win against Burnley, which he missed after being awarded the spot kick in the 10th minute. Despite concerns over penalty choices, manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley's decision, noting he was within his rights and praising his responsibility. The missed penalty was saved by Burnley's goalkeeper, Tom Heaton. The match's decisive moment came when Kevin Mirallas scored the only goal.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the cruise ship ms Ryndam in Puerto Rico, believed to be a murder-suicide. The ship, en route from Tampa to the Southern Caribbean, was in San Juan when the deaths were discovered by cleaning staff. The cruise line is cooperating with authorities, including the FBI, who are investigating the incident.

Patrick Kluivert, a former Holland player and assistant coach, has successfully begun his tenure as coach of Curacao by leading the team to advance in 2018 World Cup qualifying. Curacao progressed to the second round of CONCACAF qualification after a 2-2 draw with Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate, with a notable late goal from Charlton Vicento. The team will face Cuba in upcoming matches on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, has a notable football history, including playing in the 1998 World Cup semi-final and serving as an assistant coach at the 2014 World Cup.

Esteban Cambiasso, who has won major European trophies with teams like Inter Milan, River Plate, and Real Madrid, emphasizes that saving Leicester City from relegation would be a significant achievement comparable to winning a trophy. Despite their current position at the bottom of the Premier League with only eight games left, Cambiasso remains optimistic about their chances to avoid relegation. He joined Leicester in the summer for a one-year deal, has become a key player, and expresses happiness with his time there. He believes the team can still win matches and stay in the Premier League, and he is open to staying beyond his current contract.

A 23-year-old mother, Gemma, who neglects her children due to her drinking and partying habits, is threatened by her mother Debbie with being banned from seeing them. Debbie, who has cared for the children since they were four months old after social services intervened, criticizes Gemma's lifestyle, accusing her of stealing and using legal highs. Gemma admits to past thefts but denies stealing an iPad. Debbie, emotionally affected and exhausted by her daughter’s behavior, plans to restrict her access to the children, expressing concern over her daughter’s lack of responsibility and care.

After Eden Hazard scored for Chelsea, pundits observed that John Terry's earlier challenge on Radamel Falcao, which led to a loose ball and the subsequent goal, should have been penalized as a foul. The commentators agreed that Terry's challenge was rough and deserves punishment, although the goal itself was impressive.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway, but all on board were safely evacuated. The fire started after a rear tire blew out, causing the bus to burst into flames after everyone had exited. Scott shared that the fire destroyed everything in the back lounge except her Bible. The band’s other members were not traveling on that bus. The band is scheduled to perform at the upcoming Academy of Country Music Awards.

A Scottish scientist, Dr. Adrian Quarterman from Dundee University, is developing a laser system that converts sunlight into energy via satellites orbiting Earth, aiming to provide a future renewable energy source that could benefit regions like Scotland and disaster areas. Early trials were successful, with plans to move testing to Portugal. The lasers in his project will be much less powerful than those depicted in movies, primarily used to boost solar panel efficiency. Additionally, Tokyo researchers have proposed lasers on the ISS to target and burn up space debris, which are also not powerful enough to be weapons. Dr. Quarterman notes potential concerns over control of his satellite lasers.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a obsession with young girls, has gone on the run after disappearing from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire, where he was detained under a hospital order following his sexual offences conviction. Munden, who suffers from autism and mild learning difficulties, was last seen leaving the hospital around 6.15pm on Tuesday, and officers believe he may have shaved his beard. He was previously convicted of sexually touching a three-year-old girl and possessing indecent images of children. Authorities have launched a manhunt and seek information about his whereabouts.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to repay over $2.6 million in gifts received from Donald Sterling, after Rochelle Sterling sued her for targeting wealthy older men and for the gifts, which included luxury cars and property. Stiviano claimed her gift receiving was legitimate, but the court found in favor of the Sterling family. Donald Sterling's downfall was linked to leaked audio where he made racist remarks and disparaged social media posts showing him with African-Americans, leading the NBA to ban him, fine him $2.5 million, and terminate his ownership of the Clippers.

Thierry Henry criticized Arsenal's recent transfer activities, urging the club to sign four key players—a goalkeeper, center back, defensive midfielder, and striker—to improve their chances of winning the Premier League. He highlighted that Arsenal's current squad lacks the spine needed for title success, citing Chelsea's successful recent signings as an example. Henry also questioned Olivier Giroud's ability to lead Arsenal to the league title, noting his 14 goals this season but suggesting he may not be sufficient as the sole top striker. Overall, Henry emphasized the need for Arsenal to strengthen their squad if they are to contend for the championship.

A young woman, who was abused as a child by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, testified in Sydney's District Court about the severe life impact of the abuse. Van Ryn pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, unable to name herself publicly, explained she was unaware the abuse was wrong and only spoke out after Van Ryn’s arrest. Since then, she's experienced depression, self-harm, and suicidal thoughts, fearing how her trauma will affect her future relationships and life. Van Ryn sat silently in court during her testimony, which highlighted the lasting emotional damage caused by his actions.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder and Germany Under-21 international, is recovering from a serious knee injury that kept him out since March 2014. He recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under-21s and expressed confidence in his recovery, indicating he is feeling better and looking forward to returning to the first team.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old graduate, died after falling from a 70-foot cliff in Penarth, South Wales, while fleeing from a taxi to avoid paying his fare following a night out. He ran in the dark after his friends, who had used an ATM and decided not to pay the fare, and leapt over a fence onto the rocky terrain below. Disoriented and in the dark, he was unaware of the sheer drop nearby. His body was discovered the next day by a dog walker. An inquest concluded his death was accidental, citing his disorientation and lack of awareness of the danger.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer’s passport delays received little to no compensation, despite the passport agency making a £42 million profit and paying managers bonuses up to £3,500. Only 2,191 compensation claims were approved between April and January, totaling just over £203,000, with an average payout of about £92. Many who missed trips or paid extra for expedited services did not receive reimbursement. The Home Affairs Committee, led by Keith Vaz, called for broader compensation but was denied by ministers to avoid setting a precedent. The delays occurred during a period when the Passport Office processed 3.6 million applications and faced a substantial backlog, with scarcely any claims rejected due to system failures.

The property is a semi-detached home in Horfield, Bristol, unchanged since the 1930s, featuring original stained-glass windows, bathroom, kitchen, cupboards, and oil-fired central heating. Inside, it has vintage elements such as tiled bathrooms, wood-panelled hallways, and original produce tins on shelves. Some features have been upgraded, like double glazing, but renovation costs may deter developers. The house, valued between £200,000 and £250,000, is set to be auctioned on April 30.

Colin Kaepernick started his NFL career as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starting quarterback in 2012 after Smith's concussion. He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, though they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
"Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth 'Babyface' Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, released by Fox 2000 Pictures."

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and lived there in her early years before moving to Texas and later San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone, East London, attended Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon and formed Blur, debuting with the album "Leisure" in 1991. The band, influenced by various genres, released their self-titled album in 2001, achieving worldwide success. Albarn's solo debut, "Everyday Robots," was released on April 28, 2014, featuring collaborations with artists like Brian Eno and Natasha Khan.
Mogadishu, also known locally as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, hosting many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by Nine Inch Nails from their 1992 debut EP, Broken.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter nominated for a BAFTA award.

The passage describes two adaptations of the story of Bob Lee Swagger: the 2007 film where he is framed for murder by a rogue military unit, and the TV series where he is an exile expert marksman drawn back into action to stop a plot to kill the president.
"House (also called House, M.D.) is an American medical drama that aired on Fox for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012."

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, carried out by his followers under his instruction. He also received convictions for the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. Following his charges, recordings of songs written and performed by Manson were commercially released.

Sean Justin Penn, born on August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began acting in television and made his film debut in "Taps" (1981). Throughout the 1980s, he appeared in various films including "Fast Times at Ridgemont High" (1982) and gained critical recognition in crime dramas like "At Close Range" (1986), "State of Grace" (1990), and "Carlito's Way" (1993). He became a leading actor with the film "Dead Man Walking" (1995), earning his first Oscar nomination and the Berlin Film Festival's Best Actor Award. He received additional Oscar nominations for "Sweet and Lowdown" (1999) and "I Am Sam" (2001), winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor for "Mystic River" (2003) and a second for "Milk" (2008).

Sir Donald Bradman, also known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer regarded as the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he remained influential in cricket as an administrator, selector, and writer for thirty years.
L.A. Reid has served as chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is best known as the drummer for Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000, 2007–11) and Audioslave (2001–07). He began his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991 with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha. As of 2016, he plays in Prophets of Rage alongside other artists. The mention of Rage refers to a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.

The Millers is a multi-camera series that aired from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, on CBS, with 34 episodes over two seasons. CBS announced its cancellation on November 14, 2014, during the second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933–2006) was an American politician who served as the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. She was a Democrat, known for her outspoken feminism, and gained national attention as Texas state treasurer and keynote speaker at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. Richards was the second female governor of Texas and was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush. The passage also mentions Ann Richards (1935–1982), an American jazz singer and wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell released an independent EP titled A Reminder in 2011.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film directed by Stephen Verona, who also co-wrote it. Janet Leigh was an American actress, singer, dancer, and author, born Jeanette Helen Morrison, and she wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón Bolívar was a Venezuelan military and political leader, known as El Libertador, who played a key role in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as independent sovereign states from Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, also called the Devil's Triangle, is a region in the western North Atlantic Ocean where aircraft and ships are said to have vanished under mysterious conditions.

In the 2013 season, his first full year as a starter, he helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship, but they lost to the Seahawks.

"Private Lives" is a 1930 comedy of manners play by Noël Coward, which was adapted into a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Maurice Harold Macmillan was a British Conservative politician who served as Prime Minister of the UK from 1957 to 1963.

Aristotle (384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira. He joined Plato's Academy around age 17-18 and studied there until about age 37. After Plato's death, he left Athens and, at Philip II of Macedon's request, tutored Alexander the Great starting in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz, born February 16, 1982, is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the BeatBuddy guitar pedal drum machine and is currently the CEO of music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played as a point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, winning multiple championships and awards. He was drafted first overall in 1979, won a championship and Finals MVP in his rookie year, and secured four more titles in the 1980s. After retiring due to protests from fellow players, he returned in 1996 for 32 games before retiring permanently. Apart from basketball, he is recognized as an influential businessman and was a part-owner of the Lakers.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They have released three albums: "Tenacious D" (2001), "The Pick of Destiny" (2006), and "Rize of the Fenix" (2012). The band first gained popularity in 1997 through their TV series and supporting major rock acts.

James VI and I (1566–1625) was King of Scotland from 1567 and King of England and Ireland from 1603 until his death. He ruled the two kingdoms in personal union, with separate parliaments and laws, and advocated for a single parliament for both. While he achieved most aims in Scotland, he faced difficulties in England, including the Gunpowder Plot and conflicts with Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality TV show, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Marcus Bentley, born in 1967, is a British actor and voice-over artist, renowned for narrating the UK's version of Big Brother since 2000 and known for his distinctive voice and Geordie accent.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany, bordering several German states, Poland, and the Czech Republic. It covers 18,413 km², is the sixth most populous with 4 million people, and has a history spanning over a millennium. Saxony is also known for its wine region, one of the northernmost in Europe, and is one of the two German wine regions located in former East Germany.
East End Park was a major league baseball park in Cincinnati's East End neighborhood. The phrase "In the End" refers to a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown started her solo career with the release of "I Want You Back" featuring Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

"Mohra" is a 1994 Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, featuring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. It was the second highest grossing Indian film of 1994, received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995, and is known for its popular soundtrack. Initially, Divya Bharti was cast in the female lead but was replaced by Raveena Tandon after her death.
"Hourglass" is a song by British electronic duo Disclosure, and it is also the title of singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.
Shane Black, born December 16, 1961, is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor, known for writing the 1987 film Lethal Weapon and directing Kiss Kiss Bang Bang in 2005.
" A View to a Kill" (1985) is the fourteenth James Bond film and the last to feature Roger Moore as the MI6 agent James Bond.
Papua is Indonesia's largest eastern province, covering most of western New Guinea, and was formerly known as Irian Jaya.
Augustus likely died of natural causes, though unconfirmed rumors suggest his wife Livia may have poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez debuted in the music industry in 1999 with her album "On the 6" and her hit single "If You Had My Love." In 2001, she released her second album "J.Lo" and starred in "The Wedding Planner," becoming the first woman to have a number-one album and film in the same week. Her third album "This Is Me... Then" was influenced by her high-profile relationship with Ben Affleck. Despite a setback with the failure of "Gigli" in 2003, she married Marc Anthony, had twins in 2008, and experienced a career resurgence in 2011 as a judge on "American Idol" and with her hit single "On the Floor," one of the best-selling singles ever.

A working animal is usually domesticated and trained by humans to perform tasks such as assistance, pulling loads, milking, or herding. These animals can be close family members like guide dogs or draft animals like horses and elephants. While wild animals may sometimes be trained for work, they are typically less trustworthy and calm, and mainly used for novelty or entertainment.

"Vedam" is a 2010 Telugu Indian drama film directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi, featuring a cast including Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.
"Men in Black II" is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film starring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, and other actors.
Sancho Panza is a fictional character in Cervantes' 1605 novel Don Quixote, serving as Don Quixote's squire. He offers humorous, ironic, and earthy comments called sanchismos throughout the story.
"The Adventures of Pluto Nash" is a 2002 Australian-American science fiction action comedy film featuring Eddie Murphy in a dual role and directed by Ron Underwood.
Ibsen was present at the world premiere of Hedda Gabler on 31 January 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich.

Juventus Football Club, also known as Juve, is a professional Italian soccer team based in Turin, founded in 1897 by young students. It is the second oldest active football club in Italy and traditionally wears a black and white striped kit. The club's latest home ground is the Juventus Stadium, which has a capacity of 41,507.

Viola Davis played supporting and minor roles in various films and TV series in the late 1990s and early 2000s, including "Kate & Leopold" (2001), "Far from Heaven" (2002), and "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit."

Jenna Jameson, born Jenna Marie Massoli on April 9, 1974, is an American entrepreneur, webcam model, and former pornographic actress. She is known as the world's most famous adult entertainment performer and "The Queen of Porn." She began acting in erotic videos in 1993 after working as a stripper and glamor model.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000, originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and later via pay-per-view. It was organized by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later by World Championship Wrestling (WCW). The event was produced by Jim Crockett Promotions (JCP) under the NWA banner, with notable editions in 1985 (third annual), 1987 (fifth annual), and 1997 (fifteenth annual).
Jack Ryan Falahee, born on February 20, 1989, is an American actor known for his roles as Connor Walsh on "How to Get Away with Murder" and Benjamin Stringfellow on "Mercy Street."

Seohyun, born June 28, 1991, is a South Korean singer and actress. She debuted as a member of Girls' Generation in 2007, a highly successful girl group, and later participated in its subgroup TTS. Besides group activities, she has acted in stage musicals like Moon Embracing the Sun, Gone with the Wind, and Mamma Mia. She made her solo debut with the mini album "Do n't Say No" on January 17, 2017, becoming the third member of Girls' Generation to launch a solo career.

The Apple II is an influential 8-bit home computer designed mainly by Steve Wozniak, and introduced in 1977 by Apple Computer. It was among the first successful mass-produced microcomputers and featured a family of models with distinctive branding. Steve Wozniak, a co-founder of Apple Inc., was a key inventor and engineer behind its development.

Initially, her works received mixed reactions, but she gained greater popularity with critics and readers in the 1980s. She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years until his death in 2002 from brain cancer.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a 2010 population of 77,344, making it the 12th most populous municipality in the state. Historically, in the early 1900s, its population mainly comprised European immigrants.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film The Canyons, directed by Paul Schrader.
The Lincoln-Douglas Debates of 1858 were seven debates held in Illinois between Republican Abraham Lincoln and Democratic Senator Stephen Douglas during their campaign for the U.S. Senate.
Homer is the ancient Greek author of the central epic poems, the Iliad and the Odyssey. The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel written by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle was a US Navy SEAL veteran and sniper, born on April 8, 1974. He was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas, on February 2, 2013.

The passage discusses Audioslave, a four-member band comprising Chris Cornell, Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Brad Wilk is known for his roles in Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave and currently plays in Prophets of Rage. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, includes Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monaé Robinson, born on December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to her own label, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records. In 2010, she released her critically acclaimed debut album, *The ArchAndroid*, a concept album that follows her first EP and was released by Bad Boy Records.
"Winter's Tale" is a novel written by Mark Helprin, published in 1983.

Lake Providence is a town in northeastern Louisiana and the parish seat of East Carroll Parish. Regarding education, approximately 55% of its undergraduates and 60% of all students are from Mississippi, with 23% being minorities. The university attracts international students from 90 nations.
The series "Flaked" was renewed in July 2016 for a six-episode second season, set to premiere on June 2, 2017.
Aaron Burr was elected twice to the New York State Assembly, served as New York State Attorney General, was a U.S. senator representing New York, and ultimately became vice president.

The Soyuz rocket was developed to launch Soyuz spacecraft for the Soviet human spaceflight program, beginning with 8 unmanned test flights and then 19 manned launches. Designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau in the 1960s, it succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and was initially part of the Soviet lunar programs. It remains in service today.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine's member de la Rocha left the band in 2000 due to tensions, leading to their breakup. The band members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, releasing three albums before disbanding in 2007. Rage Against the Machine reunited in 2007, performing at Coachella after seven years. Their fourth studio album, Renegades, was released on December 5, 2000.

The S&P BSE SENSEX is a stock market index consisting of 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange, including Tata Motors, which is also listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is an easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia with approximately 92.7 million people, making it the 14th most populous globally and ninth in Asia. It borders China, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Since 2000, Vietnam has experienced high economic growth, and in 2011, it had the highest Global Growth Generators Index among major economies. It is one of the four remaining one-party socialist states that officially espouse communism.
"Dreamer" is a 2005 American sports drama film, written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut.
Bhagat Singh was an Indian socialist revolutionary known for his acts of violence against the British and his execution at age 23, which made him a folk hero of the Indian independence movement.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut with the 2016 Hindi-language biographical sports drama film "Dangal," directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I (1566–1625) was King of Scotland from 1567 and King of England and Ireland from 1603 until his death. The Scottish and English kingdoms remained separate sovereign states with their own institutions, though they were united under his rule in a personal union. He advocated for a single parliament for both nations and faced numerous challenges with Parliament during his reign in England.

Danielle Cormack, born on December 26, 1970, is a New Zealand stage and screen actress known for her roles in the soap opera Shortland Street, Xena: Warrior Princess, The Cult, Legend of the Seeker, Separation City, Rake, Underbelly: Razor, and her notable portrayal of Bea Smith in the prison drama Wentworth, where she starred for four years before departing in 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born on October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer renowned for his work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred in and co-starred in several films including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. He also co-wrote the 2015 comedy film Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, directed by Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born on August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

The album "Artpop" received mixed reviews but was commercially successful, debuting at No. 1 on the US Billboard 200 with 258,000 copies sold in the first week. It was Gaga's second consecutive US number-one album, with total US sales of 757,000 copies and 2.3 million copies sold worldwide in 2013.

In 2006, John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, Stadium Arcadium. The album was also the last to feature Frusciante, who confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She was a controversial yet highly influential figure, regarded as one of the greatest politicians in British history, though debates about Thatcherism continue.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author who has also written weekly columns on various topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who has performed acting roles and also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the Valencian Community in Spain and the third largest city in the country, with about 800,000 residents in the city and a metropolitan population between 1.7 and 2.5 million.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The series "Make It or Break It" was announced to end on April 26, 2012, with the third season being the final. The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is a multidisciplinary field that enables computers to convert spoken language into text, involving linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Its applications include voice interfaces, call routing, appliance control, search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and direct voice input for aircraft. Industry adoption of deep learning techniques has driven significant advances, with major companies like Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, and others publicly highlighting their use of deep learning in their speech recognition systems.
