Granger was found guilty of manslaughter and conspiracy to rob, while her co-defendants were convicted of murder and conspiracy charges and received life sentences. The court described the attack as pitiless and wicked, noting Granger’s deceit and her prior good deeds contrasted with her involvement in the crime driven by her relationship with Jackson.

Cesc Fàbregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has experienced a decline in form during the second half of the season, with his performance notably dropping since mid-January. Despite early success and a strong start to the season, his contributions have decreased, especially after December, with only four assists in his last 15 appearances. His international form also shows struggles, including a poor performance in Spain’s 2-0 defeat to the Netherlands. The long, intense campaign and fatigue are thought to be factors impacting his durability and influence. Although Chelsea’s season is likely to end with a Premier League title, questions remain about his late-season slump and overall consistency, with his form being crucial for both personal achievement and the club’s success.

West Ham is negotiating to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who has impressed during a two-week trial after training with their academy. Beckford, from Montego Bay United, has offers from Belgian clubs and is considered a top Caribbean prospect. Additionally, West Ham announced that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, making their prices the lowest in the Premier League to encourage attendance for the 2016-17 season.

Police have dropped their investigation into a violent assault on huntsman Mike Lane, despite extensive evidence including a video, names, and vehicle details. Lane was beaten and kicked during an attack by protesters armed with iron bars at Everleigh, near Amesbury. The police cited insufficient evidence as the reason for halting the case, causing dismay among supporters and Lane himself, who expressed distrust in law enforcement. The attackers had used chemical agents and wore face coverings, complicating efforts to identify individuals. The incident, which left Lane with injuries and memory loss, has garnered criticism for police inaction and calls for a ban on face coverings by saboteurs.

Adam Gadahn, an American-born member of al Qaeda known for his propaganda and statements against the U.S., was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January. He was a prominent figure within al Qaeda, serving as its chief English-language propagandist and producing videos threating attacks on Western targets. Gadahn, originally from California and converted to Islam, joined al Qaeda in Pakistan in the late 1990s and rose through its ranks, becoming an influential voice. He was indicted for treason in 2006 and was among the FBI's most wanted terrorists. Throughout his involvement, he publicly criticized U.S. presidents and encouraged lone-wolf attacks in the U.S. His final known video was released in September 2014. Gadahn was married with at least one child.

A viral video in China showcases five-year-old Mai Zizhuo demonstrating exceptional basketball skills, including shooting hoops and dribbling two balls simultaneously. Mai has been playing since age two and a half, and his talents have garnered widespread admiration and thousands of comments online. His remarkable abilities have captivated China's basketball fans, drawing comparisons to famed player Yao Ming.

Tom O'Carroll, a former member of the paedophile information exchange (which campaigned to legalise child sex in the 1970s and 80s), has joined supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. He attended a rally in the Houses of Parliament to lobby MPs for government regulation of the media. O'Carroll's involvement is seen as embarrassing for Hacked Off. Historically, PIE aimed to legalise sex with children and incest, and O'Carroll was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals."

On Thursday, Bondi's Icebergs Club drained its pool to serve as an unusual catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. Models showcased a monochrome, unisex capsule collection called "The Collection of Ten," designed to be worn in 20 different ways and suitable for both day and night. The event featured models walking through the empty pool and along the break wall with ocean views, attracting onlookers including beachgoers and passers-by. Guests enjoyed refreshments from Icebergs and Santa Vittoria under warm, sunny weather. The collection emphasized androgynous designs, with models seen in scarves and hoodies, reflecting a blend of fashion and the iconic seaside location.

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, enjoyed a family day at a safari park in northern California, where he spent time with his wife, Faryal Makhdoom, and daughter Lamysa, feeding a white tiger and posing with giraffes and sea lions. Recently, Khan confirmed he will fight former world champion Chris Algieri on May 30 at welterweight, despite previous pressure to face British rival Kell Brook or others like Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, whose name appeared on an Israeli memorial wall honoring fallen soldiers and terrorism victims, is set to be removed following family and organizational objections. Abu Khdeir, who was beaten and burned alive by Israelis in July, was not recognized as a terror victim by some groups, who considered his death a rogue attack. His family objected to his inclusion without permission, and an organization representing terror victims demanded his removal, asserting his death was an individual act. The Israeli National Insurance Institute plans to remove his name from the memorial after his father's complaints.

A young boy in California attempts to use his family cat as a pillow by repeatedly lying on the cat and following it around the garden. The cat initially sits and licks its fur before being plopped on by the boy, then quickly moves away. The boy continues to follow and lie on the cat multiple times. Eventually, the cat walks off indoors, but later the boy and cat are seen happily making up, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia continues, with one witness, Robert Kushner, losing his coaching job after testifying about his past marijuana dealings and police misconduct. Kushner, who sold marijuana for years and had past legal issues, testified that officers stole cash and marijuana from him during an arrest in 2007, charges which were later expunged. He maintains he is innocent of recent charges and regretful for past actions. Despite his legal troubles, Kushner is described as a good coach who cares for kids. The trial involves multiple officers accused of racketeering, with the prosecution relying on testimonies from former drug dealers.

Six people were injured in an explosion at a controversial chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province, China. The explosion, caused by an oil leak, ignited a fire that is now under control, with over 600 firefighters deployed. The plant produces paraxylene, a carcinogenic chemical used in polyester manufacturing. Residents nearby heard and saw the explosion, which occurred after a previous incident in 2013. The construction of such plants has historically led to protests due to environmental concerns, and the plant was relocated in 2007 following local backlash.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa midfielder, is known for wearing his socks just above his shinpads due to a lifelong superstition, which he refuses to change despite reminders from referees. He wears children's shinpads and has not been hit on the shin yet. Grealish made his first Premier League start in a match against QPR, which he was pleased to have finally achieved, and hopes to secure more starts before the season's end, feeling encouraged by his manager's confidence.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has sustained irreversible brain damage, remaining unresponsive and in a persistent neurological state for nearly three months. Despite her father’s earlier claim that she was awake and watching him, her grandmother and a knowledgeable source confirmed she is still in a coma-like condition, with no response to stimuli. She has a tracheostomy and cannot follow objects with her eyes. The family expresses hope for her future longevity but acknowledge the uncertain quality of her life ahead, emphasizing the long rehabilitation process she faces.

Russia is close to reaching the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki, while Svetlana Kuznetsova previously beat Julia Goerges. Pavlyuchenkova faced challenges from Lisicki's power and serving issues, and both players committed numerous errors, but Pavlyuchenkova ultimately secured the victory. Russia needs one more win from Sunday's matches to reach the final and claim their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to brace for more flooding and damage due to an upcoming storm predicted to hit later this week, potentially causing heavy rain and strong winds. The same east coast low system that affected the area last week is expected to bring rain from Thursday to Saturday, possibly impacting already flood-affected catchments. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that ongoing storms will hinder cleanup efforts, with over 4,000 jobs remaining. The Hunter region, heavily impacted by previous flooding and winds, is a particular focus of concern. Meteorologists indicate the weather system will be different from last week, with possibly less prolonged rain, and impacts expected mainly in coastal areas of northeast NSW and parts of Queensland. Authorities urge the community to prepare homes and families to prevent further devastation. Over 1,000 personnel are actively working across NSW to respond to weather-related damages.

Nina Moric, a model appearing in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, clarified that she did not attempt suicide but was hospitalized after collapsing due to low blood pressure following a domestic accident. She posted photos showing bruises on Instagram and explained she was shocked by media reports suggesting a suicide attempt. Moric stated her boyfriend was in Naples at the time and that she only needed rest. Italian media previously linked her to a 2009 overdose attempt. Moric was formerly married to Fabrizio Corona, a paparazzo jailed for blackmail, with whom she has a son.

A survey shows that the British public prefers the name Diana for the upcoming royal baby girl, with 12% supporting it, as many hope for a princess. Names like Alice and Charlotte are also popular. For a boy, James is favored by 13%. Most people prefer a girl for the baby and support William's decision to take six weeks paternity leave, with 68% approval. There is significant public and social media enthusiasm for naming the baby after William's mother, Princess Diana.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 and injuring dozens, including Afghan lawmaker Humayoon Humayoon. The protesters, heading to a rally against the provincial governor, were hit around 10 a.m. No organization claimed responsibility, and Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid denied involvement.

Dani Alves will leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Despite winning four Spanish titles and two Champions Leagues during his seven years at the club, Alves and Barcelona failed to agree on a new deal. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that Alves rejected a three-year extension contingent on playing 60% of matches, and she criticized the club for not considering renewing his contract earlier.

Pablo Osvaldo has urged Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca Juniors in Argentina. He believes they would be a great fit for the team, and that fans would love to see them play at La Bombonera. Osvaldo, who is 29 and currently on loan at Boca from Southampton, has scored three goals in six games. He feels that their playing styles would suit Boca and that they would be highly popular with the fans.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, experienced a spectacular fall from his horse during a race at Wincanton, resulting in a double somersault. Despite the dramatic fall that gained online attention, he sustained only a cut on his nose, returned to riding, and remains undeterred. The fall was described as a blur, and he acknowledged that he had been lucky. Ferguson received some banter from peers and gained extra Twitter followers, joking about considering a gymnastics career after racing.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain, dressed as Iron Man to celebrate the release of "Avengers: Age of Ultron" and shared a photo on Instagram. He returned to Wasps in 2012 after playing for Stade Français, Ricoh Black Rams in Japan, and Highlanders in New Zealand. Haskell has made over 100 appearances for Wasps and earned 57 caps for England.

The passage discusses the rising popularity of wide-leg trousers as a key SS15 trend, highlighting their effortless appeal and suitability as an alternative to skinny jeans. It notes that this style, reminiscent of the 1970s, has made multiple comebacks and emphasizes that proper styling—such as pairing with high heels and simple tops—can help shorter individuals pull off the look. Denim wide-leg trousers, like those from Gucci and Topshop, are particularly popular. The trend is versatile, suitable for both casual and dressier occasions, and can be styled easily regardless of weather, making it a timely wardrobe update.

The University of Michigan initially decided to cancel a screening of the film "American Sniper" due to objections from some students, including a petition highlighting concerns about its depiction of the Iraq war and its negative portrayal of the Middle East. However, after a backlash and a counter-petition, university officials reversed the decision, stating it was a mistake to cancel and emphasizing their commitment to free expression. The film will be shown alongside an alternative screening of "Paddington," which was praised by football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists allegedly set a quokka on fire using an aerosol spray and lighter on Rottnest Island, Western Australia. The incident occurred on April 3; the quokka survived but was singed. Detectives questioned the men, seized video evidence, evicted them from the island, and charged both with animal cruelty. They are scheduled to appear in court on April 17. Quokkas are small animals found on some islands off the west Australian coast, including Rottnest Island.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer who performed in New York nightspots in the 1930s and 1940s alongside notable entertainers, had never seen her own dance performances or her photographs before. With help from filmmakers and volunteers, a video of early music videos called "soundies" was created and shown to her at her nursing home, allowing her to see herself dancing for the first time. She was delighted by the experience.

A study reveals that the tradition of men washing their own cars in Britain is declining, with a third of men and three-quarters of women never doing it themselves. Factors include the rise of car washes, larger vehicle sizes, changing weekend routines, and less time available. Car owners are more likely to wash their cars during holidays, with larger cities showing higher frequencies. Younger cars like Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are washed more often, while Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are less frequently cleaned by owners. Overall, the practice is decreasing as more people opt for automated or professional services.

Martin Skrtel praised Steven Gerrard's significant impact at Liverpool since 2008, describing him as one of the best players in the world and synonymous with the club. Gerrard aims to end his Liverpool career by winning the FA Cup final against Arsenal before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel acknowledged Gerrard's role in helping him settle at the club and believes Liverpool can overcome the challenge of replacing him, citing potential players to fill his void. Both players are expected to return to the lineup after serving bans for prior misconduct.

At age 75, Jack Nicklaus made a hole-in-one on the 4th hole at Augusta National's par-3 contest, marking his first ace on this course. The event featured five hole-in-ones overall, tying the record since 2002, but Nicklaus's achievement was overshadowed by Camilo Villegas's record-tying holes-in-one. Nicklaus, a legendary golfer with six Masters titles and a career grand slam, expressed confidence about his game. The par-3 contest is a notable prelude to Masters week, and Nicklaus's moment added to his storied career.

Several storms in Kansas and nearby states produced tornadoes, prompting sirens and reports of damage. A tornado was observed northwest of Goddard, Kansas, near Wichita, and others were reported near Aetna in southwestern Kansas. Additionally, a possible tornado and storm damage occurred in Potosi, Missouri, with reports of wind damage, flooding, and fallen trees. The storm activity is expected to continue into Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

A reserve sheriff's deputy in Oklahoma, Robert Bates, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting Eric Harris during an arrest, claiming it was accidental and intending to use a taser. Bates was allowed to travel to the Bahamas for a family vacation during his preliminary hearing, prompting criticism from Harris's family, who viewed it as insensitive amid mourning. Bates, 73, was involved in the April 2 incident and faced allegations related to his qualifications and the treatment he received from the sheriff's office, which denies misconduct. His legal team released training documents suggesting he was properly trained. The case continues with a scheduled hearing on July 2.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title fight against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas. He has revealed a new tiger tattoo on his stomach, alongside his existing gorilla tattoo, to intimidate his opponent. McGregor has expressed confidence, claiming Aldo lacks motivation and does not want the belt as much as he does. During a promotional tour in Dublin, McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt, highlighting their tense relationship.

Tony Abbott drew criticism from anti-drinking campaigners for skolking a beer at an Australian rules event, which they say promotes binge drinking and associates masculinity with heavy drinking. Critics argue this sets a problematic culture that emphasizes quick and excessive drinking over socializing. Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott’s actions, suggesting physical activity is a healthier example. The incident, involving about six seconds to finish the schooner amid cheers, also elicited comments from opposition leader Bill Shorten and media reactions. Cultural critic Julie Roberts noted that such displays may reinforce stereotypes of heavy drinking as integral to Australian masculinity, despite changing societal attitudes towards binge drinking.

Indiana's Scott County is experiencing a significant increase in HIV cases linked to a short-term needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence, with confirmed cases rising from 106 to 120 and additional preliminary positives. The outbreak, primarily among intravenous users of the drug Opana, has prompted discussions on extending the 30-day program, which has distributed over 5,300 clean syringes to 86 participants. While health officials advocate for harm reduction, Pence opposes needle exchanges as anti-drug policies, raising concerns about promoting drug use. Legislation allowing needle exchanges could expand to other counties at risk, but support is uncertain amid fears of enabling illegal activities and funding challenges, as federal funds are banned and Pence's order did not include financial support. The outbreak has heightened debate over long-term strategies and the effectiveness of harm reduction in addressing drug-related HIV transmission.

A football fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a quiz about Arsenal, scoring 87% and impressing both her boyfriend and online supporters. The test resembled a school exam with multiple-choice questions, tasks, and instructions. Saskia answered questions about Arsenal's history, players, and related topics; she struggled with some questions but provided creative answers for others. Her boyfriend praised her achievement by grading her an 'A' and not ending their relationship. Comments on social media largely commended her knowledge and her boyfriend's dedication, though some felt he had taken things too far. Overall, the story highlights a humorous and supportive dynamic centered around Arsenal football knowledge.

Carlos Toro, a former Medellin cartel member who worked as an informant for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for US citizenship, faces deportation after retiring due to declining health. Despite his significant contributions to law enforcement, including aiding in the prosecution of notable figures like Manuel Noriega and Carlos Lehder, the DEA has not helped him acquire citizenship. Toro fears returning to Colombia, believing he would be killed, and is living in the US illegally. He remains in limbo awaiting a green card or passport, unable to access social security benefits, and considers going into hiding if necessary.

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire with kerosene after allegedly being gang-raped by five men, with her family reportedly encouraging her to remain silent. She is hospitalized in Delhi with 70% burns and is fighting for her life. The accused have been arrested. The incident has increased awareness and protests related to sexual violence in India, where recent attacks and the notorious gang rape and murder of Jyoti Singh in Delhi have drawn national and international attention.

Louis van Gaal, Manchester United's manager, dreams of beating rivals Manchester City in the upcoming derby at Old Trafford but has ruled out Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw due to fitness concerns. Despite some players being fit, Van Gaal emphasizes the importance of match fitness. United aims to improve their league position, possibly reaching third place and avoiding Champions League qualifiers, especially after City’s recent defeat. Van Gaal acknowledges City as a tough opponent, dismisses notions of motivation by revenge, and emphasizes learning from their previous loss to City. He is enthusiastic about experiencing the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford and praises the support of United’s fans.

Supporters from Arsenal and Liverpool protested against rising ticket prices by leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their match at Emirates Stadium, holding banners criticizing high costs amid a major TV rights deal. Tickets started at £64, among the highest in the Premier League. The protest aimed to raise awareness of fans' struggles with affordability, with fans citing issues like extortionate prices and the commercialization of football. Supporters from both clubs united to oppose ticket costs, emphasizing that football lacks its soul when fans cannot afford to attend. Further protests were anticipated after the match.

A newborn girl with a life-threatening liver condition called biliary atresia was saved through a liver transplant from her twin aunt, Shanell. Although her parents were unsuitable donors, Shanell volunteered immediately to donate a portion of her liver, which successfully saved the baby. The condition causes blocked or absent bile ducts, leading to jaundice and potentially liver failure if untreated. After surgery and a six-week hospital stay, the baby recovered well, needing ongoing tests and medication, and now has a chance at a normal life. Shanell expressed no hesitation, emphasizing her love and commitment to her niece.

Chelsea players, including Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian, participated in Audi's football challenge featuring various challenges such as shooting footballs into car trunks, sinking balls into convertibles, and playing over an Audi R8 net. Hazard and Ake won most rounds, but Remy and Willian ultimately secured a surprise victory, despite Willian damaging a car's wing mirror during the event.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, caused a 2013 highway crash that killed Vermont couple Amanda Murphy and Jason Timmons, who was also pregnant. Dellinger, who pleaded guilty to negligent homicide, stated during sentencing that he was not suicidal and claimed he was suffering from health issues, medication effects, and mental health problems at the time. His wife described him as a man of ethics and integrity. The crash involved Dellinger driving his pickup at over 100 mph across a median, resulting in severe injuries and instant death for the victims. He faces 12 to 24 years in prison and a wrongful death lawsuit. Prior reports indicated he had argued with his wife about medication on the day of the crash, and he had a history of health problems, including multiple sclerosis.

Lacey Spears, a woman from Kentucky, was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, with salt, leading to his death. She received a sentence of 20 years to life, which she showed no emotion upon receiving. Her ex-husband, Chris Hill, expressed on Facebook his desire for her to be placed in general population to face potential harm. Prosecutors argued that Spears' actions, driven by a need for attention and her mental illness, directly caused her son's suffering and death, despite her lawyer's request for a minimum sentence of 15 years to life, emphasizing her qualities as a loving mother. The judge described her crime as unfathomably cruel. The prosecution highlighted her repeated hospitalizations and social media posts documenting her son's medical struggles, including his final hours on life support. Spears remained silent during the trial, while her lawyer planned to appeal.

A new, improved influenza vaccine is arriving in Australia later than expected, including protection against flu strains H3N2 and B/phuket, due to previous vaccine mismatches that led to increased deaths in Europe and the US. High-risk groups, such as the young, elderly, and Indigenous Australians, will receive free shots from April 20. Experts, including Dr. Alan Hampson, emphasize the importance of vaccination for everyone, as even those not at high risk can help protect vulnerable family members. The updated vaccine is expected to better match circulating strains and potentially prevent more deaths.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are defending the site amid criticism in National Geographic magazine, which described it as lacking historical character, and concerns over potential budget cuts by the Illinois government that could threaten management. The site has recently undergone over $2.5 million in repairs and renovations, and efforts are underway to maintain and improve it. Despite the critique, visitors have expressed admiration for the tomb’s appearance. Illinois faces a financial crisis, with proposals to eliminate the state historic preservation agency responsible for the site, raising uncertainty about its future operation.

The passage discusses the resurgence of 1990s and early 2000s fashion trends, many of which are considered impractical or outdated. It highlights specific trends such as Jnco rave jeans making a comeback, bucket hats, camouflage print, and taking trends to the max with designer prints and double denim. Other trends include Ugg boots, daisy dukes, juicy couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets used as outerwear, harem trousers, and the return of highly exaggerated styles. The passage contrasts how celebrities from the past and present have influenced or continued these trends, often with modern updates. Many of these styles are viewed as things that should perhaps remain in the past.

This week featured several trending stories: four rainbows appeared over New York after heavy rain; rural China is cracking down on hiring exotic dancers at wakes; actor Robert Downey Jr. became visibly agitated during a UK interview; the Kardashian trend of lip plumping via the #kyliejennerchallenge gained popularity; 102-year-old Alice Barker participated in a historic reenactment; controversy arose over a prom-posal referencing bombs and accusations of racism; Ewan McGregor was cast as Lumière in 'Beauty and the Beast'; Johnny Depp was almost unrecognizable in the 'Black Mass' trailer; and various creative pregnancy announcements and a military dad's photobomb gained attention on social media.

Serena Williams celebrated her 700th career victory at the Miami Open with a large cake after defeating Sabine Lisicki to reach the semi-finals. She aimed to advance to the final against either Sloane Stephens or Simona Halep. The tournament also recognized Andy Murray’s 500th win with a cake. Williams's victory marked her progress in what she considers a hometown event, though her hopes of facing her sister Venus were dashed after Venus's loss. Williams regained some revenge over Lisicki, whom she previously lost to at Wimbledon 2013. Halep advanced to the semi-finals by beating Stephens.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani woman known for promoting free speech, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship, was murdered after hosting a discussion on sensitive topics like the insurgency in Baluchistan at her cafe, T2F, in Karachi. Her death highlights the dangers faced by those advocating for open dialogue and progressive values in Pakistan, where free speech is threatened and such discussions are often censored or silenced. Mahmud was celebrated as a symbol of love, tolerance, and non-violence, inspiring many despite the risks. Her activism and artistic expression, including vibrant graffiti and imagery, made her a prominent figure for secular and liberal ideals, but also drew threats and ultimately violence. Her killing has sparked mourning and reflection on the suppression of debate and dissent in the country.

The passage describes the ongoing plight of West Pakistan refugees (WPRs), primarily Hindus, who fled during the partition of India and have been denied citizenship rights in Indian-controlled Kashmir for decades. Despite living in poverty and being unable to own property or vote, they remain in refugee status due to laws that restrict their rights, rooted in fears of changing the demographic balance in the region. With recent political shifts, including the rise of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), there is cautious hope that their status may be normalized, potentially improving their living conditions. However, tensions persist, and community activists threaten to protest if their demands are not met.

Yoshinori Muto, a forward for FC Tokyo, is considering a potential move to Chelsea, who have reportedly made a £4 million offer and may loan him to Vitesse Arnhem. Muto, 22, wants to join a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential. FC Tokyo's president confirmed Chelsea's interest, while Muto indicated he is carefully thinking about the move. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho acknowledged awareness of Muto but emphasized the club's focus on acquiring talented players for competitive success, noting that commercial interests, such as their sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber, can influence transfer decisions. Coach Ranko Popovic praised Muto's intelligence, speed, confidence, and potential, suggesting he could succeed at Stamford Bridge.

The passage praises Australia's decision to allow their best players, who play overseas, to be selected for national teams, contrasting it with England’s policy of not selecting overseas-based players. It argues that this restrictive policy hampers the quality of the national teams and is outdated. The author emphasizes that talented players like Matt Giteau, Drew Mitchell, Steffon Armitage, Nick Abendanon, and Jonny Wilkinson have improved or excelled after moving abroad, and they should be eligible for selection regardless of where they play. The piece advocates for national coaches to choose the best possible team to win major tournaments like the World Cup, especially when hosting, criticizing policies that limit selections based solely on club location. It concludes by commending Australia's approach and highlighting the success of overseas players in their national teams.

The passage discusses Firechat, an app enabling off-the-grid messaging through wireless mesh networks using Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF). It allows users to communicate without internet or mobile signals by creating localized networks where devices act as nodes. To enhance signal range, Open Garden has developed Greenstone, a small egg-shaped device functioning as a beacon or booster within these mesh networks, extending message reach beyond the typical 200 feet limit. Greenstone is designed for resilient communication in areas lacking connectivity, such as at events or in remote locations, and currently works within a 20-foot range on Firechat, holding up to 1,000 messages with a one-year battery life. Open Garden is working to produce and sell Greenstone in partnership with manufacturers.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, advocates for body positivity by redefining 'fat' as an honest self-descriptor rather than an insult. She emphasizes that beauty exists in larger bodies and highlights the increase in size discrimination. Bustle promotes exposure to diverse body types to foster acceptance and shares her empowering experience performing burlesque, which normalized her body and boosted her confidence. Despite some negative comments, her TED talk has received mostly positive feedback, inspiring others to reconsider societal standards of attractiveness and embrace body diversity.

Theo Walcott, an Arsenal winger often overlooked this season, was recently photographed during a photoshoot with fellow players and model Olga Sherer for Lanvin, the club's official tailor. Despite spending much of the season on the bench, Walcott has appeared as a substitute in 17 of 33 Premier League games and recently played the last six minutes in a match against Chelsea. He hopes to start in Arsenal's upcoming game against Hull after his last starting appearance in March.

An auction will be held on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online at propstore.com, featuring a collection of over 400 props and puppets created by make-up effects artist Rick Baker. The collection, valued at approximately $746,100, includes items from more than 50 productions such as "Men in Black," "Batman Forever," "How the Grinch Stole Christmas," and others. Notable items include an alien Edgar bug from "Men in Black" estimated at $40,000, a Michael Jackson transformation face from "Moonwalker" valued at $3,000, and costumes and puppets like the Grinch suit from Jim Carrey's film and a bat puppet from "Batman Forever." The auction offers fans and collectors the opportunity to acquire pieces of Hollywood history, with some items expected to fetch more than their estimates.

Seven-year-old British boy Carwyn Scott-Howell died after falling from a 164-foot drop while skiing in the French Alps. He became separated from his family, entered dense woodland, and was later found dead by footprints in the snow. Described as a daring and outgoing child who started skiing at age three, he was on a holiday with happy memories prior to the tragedy. His family expressed immense grief, recalling his loving and lively nature, and highlighted his admiration for adventure, modeling himself after Bear Grylls. The community and his school in Wales mourn his loss, with condolences emphasizing his bright personality and the profound impact of his death.

The passage describes the story of 15-year-old Laura Scurr from Whitley Bay, who suffered from anorexia due to pressures to be a "size zero" and her obsession with thinness. Starting around age 13, Laura engaged in extreme dieting, hiding food, and consuming as little as one piece of fruit daily, which led to her body shutting down and collapsing at home, requiring hospitalization and a week on a heart monitor. She developed anorexia, a serious mental health condition marked by extreme weight loss, body image issues, and obsessive behaviors. Influenced by bullying and societal pressure to look thin, Laura's health deteriorated, but she received help from medical and mental health services. Now recovered, she has gained confidence and reached the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a competition promoting positive body image and confidence among young girls, countering size zero stereotypes.

Raheem Sterling was presented with Liverpool's new home kit for the 2015/16 season at Anfield, where supporters expressed their expectation for him to stay. The new kit, designed by New Balance under its record-breaking £300 million deal with Liverpool, features a "hold nothing back" message and tributes to the Hillsborough disaster. Several players, including Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet, participated in the launch, which drew large crowds. Despite Sterling's recent rejection of a £100,000-a-week contract and rumors of a move to Arsenal, Liverpool assert he will remain with the club. The players also focused on upcoming matches, notably the FA Cup semi-final at Wembley, which Sterling identified as special due to his hometown connection. The kit's design includes white branding, a new collar style, and features the memorial flame and number 96 in tribute to Hillsborough casualties. Liverpool legends Robbie Fowler and Ian Rush attended the launch.

The passage describes the creation of the largest high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the night sky, with plans to eventually map 12.5%. This map, produced by University of Manchester researchers using data from the Dark Energy Camera at the Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile, shows dark matter clumps and helps scientists understand galaxy formation and the universe's expansion. Since dark matter is invisible, its presence is inferred through gravitational lensing effects on galaxy shapes. The survey analyzes 130 million galaxy images over two years, employing advanced supercomputers, and aims to produce a 3D cosmic map that will shed light on dark energy and the large-scale structure of the universe.

Manchester United have officially approached PSV Eindhoven to sign Memphis Depay, a 21-year-old Dutch winger and top scorer this season with 20 league goals. Van Gaal, who managed Depay during the 2014 World Cup, is keen to make him one of his first signings and is familiar with his qualities. PSV's technical director stated that United and Paris Saint-Germain have been in contact, with the transfer now involving larger sums of money. Depay, considered highly talented with rapid dribbling and scoring ability, has been compared favorably to stars like Arjen Robben and Cristiano Ronaldo. He played a key role in PSV's Dutch championship win and has been highly praised by teammates and scouts for his athleticism and potential.

Chelsea led 3-1 against Manchester City after a strong first-half performance, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a late goal. Chelsea's attack was lively, with Abraham's goals and Solanke's impactful presence. City responded with a goal from Isaac Buckley-Ricketts and had opportunities to equalize but were largely contained by Chelsea's solid defense, featuring players like Fikayo Tomori, Jake Clarke-Salter, and Jay Dasilva. Chelsea's midfield was controlled by Charlie Colkett, and Charly Musonda provided creative playmaking, though less impactful than usual. City’s injuries affected their performance, notably Kean Bryan, who was injured early. Key City players included Ola Aina and Ruben Sammut, who contributed defensively and offensively. The match showcased young talents from both sides, with Chelsea maintaining control and securing the victory.

Marco Rubio stated that he believes people are born with a sexual preference and that same-sex marriage should be decided by state legislatures, not courts. He emphasized that he is not against gay marriage but believes it should not be a constitutional right and that the definition of marriage is between one man and one woman. Rubio also expressed that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a person he cares about, despite disagreeing with their decision, highlighting his respect and love for family and friends regardless of their choices.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a couple who met in Riga in 2011, have been cycling around the world for nearly a year without plans or a fixed agenda. They have traveled nearly 7,000 miles across 16 countries, living minimally by camping, staying with hosts through websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, and relying on free accommodations. They survive on very low costs, mainly food costing about 2.74 euros daily, and enjoy taking in scenic views and cultural experiences. Their journey started in London and took them through Europe, Turkey, Georgia, Armenia, and onwards toward Asia, with plans to eventually cycle across the Americas. They aim to live simply, funding their adventure through homemade meals, wild foraging, and kindness from strangers, all while pursuing their dream of exploring the planet pedal by pedal.

A Texas couple, married in 2012, alleges that their photographer, James Evans of Premiere Photos, wrote a racist slur on photo booth images from their wedding. The couple, who did not know until months later, is suing for negligence and breach of contract under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, seeking at least an apology. Evans denies the allegations, claiming no evidence links his company to the offensive captions and that the couple showed no signs of mental anguish. Mediation is scheduled, with a trial set for July if no settlement is reached.

Mike Brown, an England full-back, is adopting a cautious approach to recovery from his recent concussion, unsure when he will return to play for Harlequins. Following a concussion sustained after the France game, he experienced headaches and recognized the importance of symptoms awareness, which led him to withdraw from upcoming matches, including the England-Ireland Six Nations game. Brown emphasizes not rushing back to avoid long-term issues, citing examples like Johnny Sexton and George North, who have suffered multiple concussions. North has been advised not to play further this season and is consulting a neurosurgeon. Brown's understanding of concussion symptoms has been enhanced through online education modules, which highlight the risks of returning too soon. He advises others to prioritize safety over playing through injury, sharing his experience as part of Land Rover's 'We Deal in Real' campaign promoting safety, grassroots rugby, and responsible decision-making.

The passage suggests that smartphone use and increased technological connectivity are contributing to a decline in the frequency of sexual activity among UK couples, with men's average sexual encounters dropping from five times per month in 1990 to three times in recent years. Expert Professor David Spiegelhalter attributes this decline to the erosion of boundaries between work and home, leading to busier lives and less private time, as well as increased reliance on digital communication that keeps individuals constantly connected. This, according to researchers, results in diminished priorities for intimacy and less focus on partners.

Tibetan mastiffs, once prized for their loyalty and used for herding in Tibet, have experienced a dramatic decline in popularity in China due to government anti-corruption measures and city bans on large dogs. Previously highly expensive, some sold for up to £1.2 million, but now they are being sent to slaughterhouses or stolen for meat and leather. The breed's market collapse is linked to cross-breeding, poor-quality dogs, and urbanization, leading to cruelty and a significant drop in demand.

The survey of 600 women around Paris revealed that every woman experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half suffering their first incident before age 18. Harassment ranged from insults and intimidating behaviors to sexual assault and rape. The report highlighted that such harassment often goes unreported due to conditioning and invisibility, limiting women's freedom and prompting them to alter their routines to avoid danger, thereby excluding them from public life. The findings led to calls for campaigns to reduce sexist and threatening behaviors on buses and trains, emphasizing the need for better education for women about what constitutes harassment and for measures to hold offenders accountable.

A Leeds-based company, Direct Line, ran a competition called #everydayfix to design prototypes addressing common daily emergencies such as forgetting to lock the door, losing keys, or running out of phone battery. Participants from London-based Makerversity created solutions like the 'Snooze' alarm clock to improve sleep, the 'Forget Me Lock' to indicate if the door is locked, and 'Nipper,' a small battery-powered phone charger. The most popular problem identified was sleep issues, leading to the development of 'Snooze.' Voting occurs via Twitter, with the most retweeted product entering a Kickstarter campaign. Additional solutions not shortlisted included a bone conduction helmet with navigation, a parking alert device, and an app for messaging when phone batteries die.

A police crime commissioner, Vera Baird, is under investigation for allocating over £500,000 of public funds to a charity she runs with Northumbria's chief constable, Sue Sim. Both sit on the charity's top table, raising concerns about conflicts of interest. Critics describe her selection of the charity as inappropriate, and an investigation by the Ministry of Justice is underway to determine if conflict of interest rules were violated. The funds were allocated following a new rule permitting police and crime commissioners to commission victims' services, a change introduced by the Home Secretary. Vera Baird defends her decision, asserting all protocols were followed. The controversy has been further fueled by allegations of misconduct and bullying within the force and questions about the appropriateness of the charity's funding and governance.

Three individuals—corry 'Corey' Campbell, Sandra Ng, and Carl Halin—were involved in a brutal assault on Greg Valecce, who was beaten, tied to a chair, and tattooed with offensive images over three days in Mayfair, Philadelphia. Campbell, the gang's ringleader, believed Valecce had harmed his cat and stolen money and weed. The assault included filming and resulted in severe injuries to Valecce. Campbell was sentenced to 20 years in prison, Halin to the same duration, and Ng received 23 months. Two other people, David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt, are awaiting sentencing and trial, respectively.

Manchester United have officially approached PSV Eindhoven to sign Memphis Depay, a 21-year-old Dutch winger and PSV's top scorer with 20 goals this season. Van Gaal, United's manager, who is familiar with Depay from the 2014 World Cup, is eager to make him one of his first signings. Depay has attracted interest from other top European clubs, including Paris Saint-Germain, and previously rejected Tottenham's bid. He has a prolific scoring record, a strong playing style, and is considered a talented player capable of rivaling or surpassing players like Cristiano Ronaldo and Arjen Robben. Depay played a key role in PSV's Dutch championship victory and has a background of representing the Netherlands in the World Cup, where he scored important goals.

Chelsea led Manchester City 3-1 after a strong performance, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a third late in the game. City’s Isaac Buckley Ricketts scored to bring City back to 2-1, with other City players like Aaron Nemane and Brandon Barker making notable attempts. Chelsea's defense, featuring players like Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, was solid, while their attack, including Abraham and Solanke, was effective. The match showcased performances from promising youth players on both sides, with Chelsea’s dominant midfield and defense, and City’s energetic but ultimately unsuccessful efforts to level the score.

Marco Rubio claimed that people are born with a sexual preference and believes same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right, stating that marriage definitions are regulated by states and should be decided through political debate rather than courts. He expressed that he would attend a family member or staffer's same-sex wedding despite disagreeing with the decision and emphasized respecting loved ones' choices. Rubio also noted that, as a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong but would still love someone who is divorced. He announced his presidential bid, with substantial donor support.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a couple who met in Riga in 2011, are cycling around the world on an open-ended journey driven by a desire to explore different places at a relaxed pace. They left their restaurant jobs in Manchester and have traveled nearly 7,000 miles across 16 countries in 356 days, living austerely on less than three euros daily by camping, couchsurfing, and relying on free accommodation. Their journey emphasizes simple living, minimal expenses, and experiencing diverse landscapes, from Europe through Turkey, with plans to continue into Asia and eventually across the Pacific and the Americas.

Mike Brown, an England full-back, is cautiously recovering from a recent concussion and remains unsure of his return date. He emphasized the importance of being cautious and not rushing back, citing awareness of concussion symptoms and the risks of long-term injury. Brown previously suffered a concussion in England's match against Italy and pulled out of the game against Ireland after recognizing symptoms. Leading medics advised Northampton wing George North not to play for the rest of the season after four concussions, and Johnny Sexton was stood down for 12 weeks earlier. Brown advocates for honesty about symptoms and highlights the value of education on concussion dangers, which influenced his decision to delay his return.

A leading expert suggests that the decline in sexual activity among couples may be linked to increased smartphone and internet use. Research shows Britons have reduced their average sexual frequency from five times a month in 1990 to three times now. Professor David Spiegelhalter attributes this decline to the pervasive integration of technology into daily life, which blurs boundaries between work and home, making people busier and less focused on intimate time. Additionally, increased single living and competing demands may contribute, with late-night work emails preventing couples from prioritizing sex.

Tibetan mastiffs, once highly prized and sold for up to £1.2 million, have faced a dramatic decline in popularity in China due to government anti-corruption measures, city bans on large dog ownership, and changing urban lifestyles. This has led to many being sent to slaughterhouses or stolen for meat, with animal welfare groups rescuing dozens from such fates. The breed's reputation has deteriorated due to cross-breeding driven by profit, resulting in poor-quality dogs and over-supply. The breed's decline is also linked to its unsuitability for city living and the fading symbol of status they once represented.

The passage describes a competition called #everydayfix, by Leeds-based Direct Line, where groups design prototypes to address common daily emergencies identified through a survey of 2,000 people. The top emergencies include issues like difficulty sleeping, losing keys, and phone battery depletion. Three finalist products—'Snooze' (an alarm clock that silences notifications), 'Forget Me Lock' (a device to confirm if your door is locked), and 'Nipper' (a portable phone charger using household batteries)—are chosen via social media voting for a Kickstarter campaign. Additional concepts that didn't make the shortlist include a cycling helmet with bone conduction headphones, a parking space alert, and a phone message relay app. The event aims to develop simple, innovative solutions to everyday problems.

The 2009 convention featured over 512 guests and musical performers, including notable figures such as Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.

The 2009 convention hosted over 6,000 guests and musical performers, including notable figures such as Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.
